canonical_explanation.text: Sound is a form of energy produced by vibrating objects. It travels as a longitudinal wave through a material medium by creating compressions (regions of high pressure) and rarefactions (regions of low pressure). Sound cannot travel through a vacuum. The speed of sound depends on the medium: it is fastest in solids, slower in liquids, and slowest in gases. In air at 20°C, the speed of sound is approximately 344 m/s. The key characteristics of sound are frequency (determines pitch, measured in Hz), amplitude (determines loudness), and wavelength. The relationship v = fλ connects speed, frequency, and wavelength. Sound reflects from surfaces following the laws of reflection. An echo is a reflected sound heard separately, requiring a minimum distance of about 17.2 m. Humans can hear sounds from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Frequencies below 20 Hz are infrasound and above 20,000 Hz are ultrasound. Ultrasound has many applications including SONAR and medical imaging.
rules: Sound is produced by vibrating objects.
Sound travels as longitudinal waves through a material medium.
Sound cannot travel through a vacuum.
Speed of sound: solids > liquids > gases.
Speed of sound in air ≈ 344 m/s at 20°C.
Frequency determines pitch; amplitude determines loudness.
Echo: reflected sound heard after the original sound.
Minimum distance for echo ≈ 17.2 m (in air at 20°C).

questions.question_text: Sound is produced by:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound is produced when an object vibrates. The vibrating object creates disturbances in the surrounding medium, which travel as sound waves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Stationary or objects at rest do not produce sound. While some rotating objects produce sound, it is due to vibrations, not rotation itself. All sound originates from vibrations.

questions.question_text: Sound travels in the form of:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound travels as longitudinal waves, where particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation, creating compressions and rarefactions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Transverse waves have perpendicular particle vibrations (like light). Electromagnetic waves don't need a medium. Sound specifically travels as longitudinal waves.

questions.question_text: Sound cannot travel through:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound requires a material medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. It cannot travel through a vacuum because there are no particles to transmit the vibrations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound can travel through solids, liquids, and gases. It requires a material medium with particles. A vacuum has no particles, so sound cannot propagate through it.

questions.question_text: In a longitudinal wave, the region of high pressure and high density is called:
questions.explanation_correct: In a longitudinal wave, a compression is a region where particles are closely packed together, resulting in high pressure and high density. Rarefaction is the opposite — low pressure and low density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rarefaction is a region of low pressure. Crests and troughs are features of transverse waves. In longitudinal waves, the high-pressure region is called a compression.

questions.question_text: Which experiment demonstrates that sound needs a medium to travel?

options.text: Bell jar experiment with vacuum pump

questions.explanation_correct: The bell jar experiment demonstrates this: a ringing bell is placed inside a jar from which air is gradually pumped out. As the vacuum increases, the sound becomes fainter and eventually inaudible, proving sound needs a medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The bell jar experiment with a vacuum pump directly demonstrates that sound cannot travel without a medium. As air is removed, the sound fades, proving the need for a material medium.

questions.question_text: The number of oscillations per second is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency is the number of oscillations (or vibrations) per second. Its SI unit is Hertz (Hz), where 1 Hz = 1 oscillation per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amplitude is the maximum displacement. Wavelength is the distance between two consecutive compressions or rarefactions. Time period is the time for one oscillation. Frequency is oscillations per second.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of frequency is the Hertz (Hz), named after Heinrich Hertz. 1 Hz means one oscillation per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Second is the unit of time, metre is the unit of length, and decibel is the unit of sound intensity level. The SI unit of frequency is the Hertz (Hz).

questions.question_text: The speed of sound is related to frequency and wavelength by the formula:
questions.explanation_correct: The relationship between speed (v), frequency (f), and wavelength (λ) is v = fλ. This applies to all types of waves, including sound waves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct wave equation is v = fλ (speed = frequency × wavelength). This is a fundamental relationship for all waves.

questions.question_text: A sound wave has a frequency of 256 Hz and a wavelength of 1.35 m. What is the speed of sound?
questions.explanation_correct: v = fλ = 256 × 1.35 = 345.6 m/s. This is close to the actual speed of sound in air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v = fλ: v = 256 × 1.35 = 345.6 m/s. 189.6 divides instead of multiplying. The correct speed is 345.6 m/s.

questions.question_text: Which property of sound determines its pitch?
questions.explanation_correct: Pitch is determined by frequency. A higher frequency produces a higher pitch (shriller sound), and a lower frequency produces a lower pitch (bass sound).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amplitude determines loudness, not pitch. Wavelength and speed are related to frequency but do not directly determine pitch. Pitch depends on frequency.

questions.question_text: Which property of sound determines its loudness?
questions.explanation_correct: Loudness is determined by the amplitude of the sound wave. Greater amplitude means louder sound. Amplitude represents the maximum displacement of particles from their mean position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency determines pitch, not loudness. The loudness of a sound depends on its amplitude — the larger the amplitude, the louder the sound.

questions.question_text: The time period of a sound wave is 0.02 s. What is its frequency?
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency = 1/Time period = 1/0.02 = 50 Hz. The wave completes 50 oscillations per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: f = 1/T = 1/0.02 = 50 Hz. 20 Hz would correspond to T = 0.05 s. The correct frequency is 50 Hz.

questions.question_text: Speed of sound in air is fastest at:
questions.explanation_correct: The speed of sound in air increases with temperature. At higher temperatures, air molecules move faster and transmit sound more quickly. Among the options, 100°C gives the fastest speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed of sound in air increases with temperature because molecules have more kinetic energy. 100°C is the highest temperature listed, so sound travels fastest at 100°C.

questions.question_text: Sound travels fastest in:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound travels fastest in solids (like steel) because the particles are most closely packed, allowing vibrations to transfer more quickly. Speed: solids > liquids > gases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound cannot travel through vacuum. Among material media, speed of sound is fastest in solids (steel ≈ 5960 m/s), then liquids (water ≈ 1482 m/s), then gases (air ≈ 344 m/s).

questions.question_text: A sound wave has a speed of 340 m/s and frequency of 680 Hz. What is its wavelength?
questions.explanation_correct: λ = v/f = 340/680 = 0.5 m. The wavelength of this sound wave is 0.5 metres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v = fλ → λ = v/f = 340/680 = 0.5 m. 2 m would be f/v (inverted). The correct wavelength is 0.5 m.

questions.question_text: A reflected sound heard after the original sound is called:
questions.explanation_correct: An echo is a sound that is heard after being reflected from a distant surface. For an echo to be heard distinctly, the reflected sound must reach the ear at least 0.1 seconds after the original sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reverberation is the persistence of sound due to multiple reflections. Resonance involves matching frequencies. Refraction is bending of waves. A clearly heard reflected sound is an echo.

questions.question_text: The minimum distance required to hear an echo in air at 20°C is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: For an echo, the time gap must be at least 0.1 s. In 0.1 s, sound travels 344 × 0.1 = 34.4 m. Since the sound must go to the wall and back, minimum distance = 34.4/2 = 17.2 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Minimum distance = (speed × minimum time)/2 = (344 × 0.1)/2 = 17.2 m. The factor of 2 accounts for the sound travelling to the reflecting surface and back.

questions.question_text: Reverberation is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Reverberation is the persistence of sound in a room after the source has stopped. It is caused by multiple reflections of sound from walls, ceiling, and floor of an enclosed space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A single reflection produces an echo. Multiple reflections cause reverberation — the overlapping of many reflected sounds that makes the sound seem to linger.

questions.question_text: To reduce reverberation in an auditorium, the walls should be:
questions.explanation_correct: Soft, porous materials like curtains, carpets, and acoustic panels absorb sound energy instead of reflecting it. This reduces multiple reflections and hence reduces reverberation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hard, smooth surfaces (glass, metal) reflect sound well and increase reverberation. Soft, porous materials absorb sound and reduce reverberation.

questions.question_text: A boy claps near a cliff and hears the echo after 1 second. How far is the cliff from the boy? (Speed of sound = 340 m/s)
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = speed × time = 340 × 1 = 340 m. This is the round trip (to cliff and back). Distance to cliff = 340/2 = 170 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound travels to the cliff and back: total distance = 340 m. Distance to cliff = 340/2 = 170 m. 340 m is the total round-trip distance.

questions.question_text: The range of hearing for humans is:
questions.explanation_correct: The audible range for normal human hearing is 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (20 kHz). Sounds below 20 Hz are infrasonic and above 20,000 Hz are ultrasonic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The human ear can detect sounds from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. This range varies slightly with age, but 20 Hz to 20 kHz is the standard audible range.

questions.question_text: Sounds of frequency less than 20 Hz are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Sounds with frequency below 20 Hz are called infrasound (or infrasonic sound). They are below the lower limit of human hearing. Elephants and whales can produce and hear infrasound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ultrasound is above 20,000 Hz. Audible sound is 20-20,000 Hz. Infrasound is specifically sounds below 20 Hz, below the threshold of human hearing.

questions.question_text: Sounds of frequency greater than 20,000 Hz are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Sounds with frequency above 20,000 Hz (20 kHz) are called ultrasound. They are above the upper limit of human hearing. Bats and dolphins use ultrasound for navigation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Infrasound is below 20 Hz. Audible sound is 20-20,000 Hz. Ultrasound is specifically sounds above 20,000 Hz.

questions.question_text: SONAR uses which type of sound waves?
questions.explanation_correct: SONAR (Sound Navigation and Ranging) uses ultrasonic waves. These high-frequency waves are sent out, and their reflection from underwater objects is used to determine distance and location.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SONAR uses ultrasonic waves (not electromagnetic, infrasonic, or audible). Ultrasound is preferred because it has high energy, travels long distances in water, and gives precise measurements.

questions.question_text: Which animal uses ultrasound for navigation?
questions.explanation_correct: Bats use ultrasound for navigation through echolocation. They emit ultrasonic waves that reflect off objects, and bats use the returning echoes to detect the location and size of obstacles and prey.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Elephants use infrasound for communication. While whales use sound, bats specifically use ultrasound (echolocation) to navigate in the dark and locate prey.

questions.question_text: Which part of the human ear converts sound vibrations into electrical signals?
questions.explanation_correct: The cochlea in the inner ear converts mechanical vibrations into electrical nerve impulses. These electrical signals are then sent to the brain via the auditory nerve for interpretation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pinna collects sound. The ear canal channels it. The eardrum vibrates. The cochlea converts these vibrations into electrical signals that the brain interprets as sound.

questions.question_text: The eardrum is also called the:
questions.explanation_correct: The eardrum is also called the tympanic membrane. It is a thin, cone-shaped membrane that vibrates when sound waves reach it, transferring the vibrations to the three small bones in the middle ear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cochlea is in the inner ear. The pinna is the outer ear. The auditory nerve carries signals to the brain. The eardrum is specifically called the tympanic membrane.

questions.question_text: The three small bones (ossicles) in the middle ear amplify vibrations and transmit them to the inner ear. These bones are called:
questions.explanation_correct: The three ossicles are the hammer (malleus), anvil (incus), and stirrup (stapes). They amplify the vibrations from the eardrum and transmit them to the cochlea in the inner ear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The three small bones in the middle ear are specifically the hammer, anvil, and stirrup. They form a chain that amplifies and transmits vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear.

questions.question_text: A tuning fork vibrates 512 times in one second. If the speed of sound in air is 340 m/s, what is the wavelength of the sound produced?
questions.explanation_incorrect: λ = v/f = 340/512 ≈ 0.66 m. 1.5 m and 6.6 m are too large, and 0.066 m is too small. The correct wavelength is approximately 0.66 m.

questions.question_text: A ship sends an ultrasonic signal and receives the echo from the ocean floor in 2 seconds. If the speed of sound in water is 1500 m/s, what is the depth of the ocean at that point?
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = v × t = 1500 × 2 = 3000 m. This is the round trip (to floor and back). Depth = 3000/2 = 1500 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The signal travels to the ocean floor and back: total distance = 3000 m. Depth = 3000/2 = 1500 m. 3000 m is the round-trip distance.

questions.question_text: Ultrasound is used in medical diagnosis because:

options.text: It can be heard by humans
It can form images of internal organs by reflection
It travels slowly in body tissues

questions.explanation_correct: Ultrasound is used in medical imaging (ultrasonography) because ultrasonic waves reflect off internal organs and tissues at different rates. These reflections are processed by a computer to form images of internal structures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ultrasound is beyond human hearing range. It has high energy and travels through body tissues. Its main medical advantage is that reflections from organs create detailed images without surgery.

questions.question_text: When we hear thunder much after we see lightning, it is because:

options.text: Light travels much faster than sound
Our eyes are more sensitive than ears

questions.explanation_correct: Lightning and thunder occur simultaneously, but light travels at 3 × 10⁸ m/s while sound travels at about 340 m/s. Light reaches us almost instantly, but sound takes much longer, creating the delay.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lightning and thunder are produced at the same time. The delay occurs because light (3 × 10⁸ m/s) is about 1 million times faster than sound (340 m/s), so we see the flash before hearing the thunder.

questions.question_text: A woman has a shriller voice than a man. This means the woman's voice has:
questions.explanation_correct: A shriller voice has a higher pitch, which corresponds to a higher frequency. Women generally have shorter vocal cords that vibrate faster, producing higher frequency sounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shrillness (higher pitch) is associated with higher frequency, not amplitude (which determines loudness) or wavelength (which is inversely related to frequency).

questions.question_text: Which application uses ultrasound to clean hard-to-reach parts of objects?
questions.explanation_correct: Ultrasonic cleaning uses high-frequency ultrasound waves to agitate a fluid, creating tiny bubbles that dislodge dirt and contaminants from surfaces. It is used to clean surgical instruments, electronic parts, and jewelry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: SONAR detects underwater objects. Echocardiography images the heart. A stethoscope uses audible sound. Ultrasonic cleaning specifically uses ultrasound to clean delicate or hard-to-reach parts.

questions.question_text: Sound can travel through vacuum.
questions.explanation_correct: False. Sound is a mechanical wave that requires a material medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to propagate. A vacuum has no particles, so sound cannot travel through it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound cannot travel through vacuum. It requires particles to transmit vibrations. This is why astronauts in space cannot hear each other without radios.

questions.question_text: Higher frequency sounds have a higher pitch.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Pitch is directly related to frequency. Sounds with higher frequency are perceived as having a higher pitch (shriller), while sounds with lower frequency have a lower pitch (bass).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Frequency determines pitch — higher frequency means higher pitch. This is why a whistle (high frequency) sounds shriller than a drum (low frequency).

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in water is greater than in air but less than in steel.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Speed of sound: steel (~5960 m/s) > water (~1482 m/s) > air (~344 m/s). Sound travels fastest in solids because particles are most closely packed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. The order is solids > liquids > gases. Steel (solid) > water (liquid) > air (gas) for speed of sound.

questions.question_text: An echo can be heard when the reflecting surface is only 5 m away from the source.
questions.explanation_correct: False. The minimum distance for hearing an echo is about 17.2 m. At 5 m, the reflected sound reaches the ear within 0.03 s, which is less than the 0.1 s needed for the brain to distinguish it from the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The minimum distance is approximately 17.2 m. At 5 m, the reflection returns too quickly (in ~0.03 s) for our brain to perceive it as a separate sound.

questions.question_text: Dogs can hear ultrasonic sounds that humans cannot.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Dogs can hear frequencies up to about 65,000 Hz, well beyond the human limit of 20,000 Hz. This is why dog whistles, which produce ultrasonic sounds, are inaudible to humans but can be heard by dogs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dogs have a hearing range of approximately 67 Hz to 65,000 Hz, which extends into the ultrasonic range that humans cannot hear.

questions.question_text: If the frequency of a sound is doubled while the speed remains constant, the wavelength is halved.
questions.explanation_correct: True. From v = fλ, if v is constant: λ = v/f. Doubling f gives λ' = v/(2f) = λ/2. The wavelength is halved when frequency is doubled.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since v = fλ and v is constant, λ is inversely proportional to f. Doubling frequency halves the wavelength.

questions.question_text: Sound travels in the form of ___ waves.
questions.explanation_correct: Sound travels as longitudinal waves, where particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation, creating alternating compressions and rarefactions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'longitudinal'. In longitudinal waves, particles vibrate along the direction of wave propagation.

questions.question_text: The time taken for one complete oscillation is called the ___ of the wave.
questions.explanation_correct: The time period (T) is the time taken for one complete oscillation. It is the reciprocal of frequency: T = 1/f. Its SI unit is the second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'time period'. It is measured in seconds and is related to frequency by T = 1/f.

questions.question_text: The persistence of sound in an enclosed space due to multiple reflections is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Reverberation is the persistence of sound after the source has stopped, caused by multiple reflections from walls, ceiling, and floor in an enclosed space.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An echo is a single distinct reflected sound. Resonance is matching natural frequencies. Diffraction is bending around obstacles. Multiple reflections causing lingering sound is reverberation.

questions.question_text: Sounds with frequency above 20,000 Hz are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Ultrasound refers to sound waves with frequencies above 20,000 Hz (20 kHz), above the upper limit of human hearing. Ultrasound has applications in medicine, industry, and navigation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ultrasound'. These frequencies are beyond human hearing and are used in applications like SONAR and medical imaging.

questions.question_text: The technique of using ultrasound to measure the depth of the sea is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: SONAR (Sound Navigation and Ranging) is a technique that uses ultrasonic waves to measure the depth of the sea and detect underwater objects. It sends out ultrasonic pulses and measures the time for the echo to return.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'SONAR'. It stands for Sound Navigation and Ranging and uses ultrasonic waves for underwater detection and distance measurement.

questions.question_text: A person standing between two parallel cliffs fires a gun. He hears the first echo after 2 seconds and the second echo after 3 seconds. What is the distance between the two cliffs? (Speed of sound = 340 m/s)
questions.explanation_correct: Distance to cliff 1 = (340 × 2)/2 = 340 m. Distance to cliff 2 = (340 × 3)/2 = 510 m. Total distance between cliffs = 340 + 510 = 850 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cliff 1 distance = v × t₁ / 2 = 340 m. Cliff 2 distance = v × t₂ / 2 = 510 m. Distance between cliffs = 340 + 510 = 850 m.

questions.question_text: A source produces 40 compressions and 40 rarefactions in 0.4 seconds. If the distance between a compression and the next rarefaction is 0.5 m, what is the speed of the wave?
questions.explanation_correct: 40 compressions and 40 rarefactions = 40 complete oscillations in 0.4 s. Frequency = 40/0.4 = 100 Hz. Distance between compression and next rarefaction = λ/2 = 0.5 m, so λ = 1 m. Speed = fλ = 100 × 1 = 100 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: f = 40/0.4 = 100 Hz. λ = 2 × 0.5 = 1 m (compression to rarefaction is half a wavelength). v = fλ = 100 m/s.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an application of ultrasound?

options.text: Measuring the depth of the ocean

questions.explanation_correct: Ultrasound is above the human hearing range (>20,000 Hz), so it cannot be used for human verbal communication. It is used for detecting metal flaws, medical imaging, and ocean depth measurement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Humans cannot hear ultrasound, so it cannot be used for communication. All other options (metal flaw detection, medical imaging, SONAR) are valid applications of ultrasound.

questions.question_text: The function of the pinna (outer ear) is to:

options.text: Collect and direct sound waves into the ear canal

questions.explanation_correct: The pinna (the visible part of the outer ear) collects sound waves from the surroundings and directs them into the ear canal toward the eardrum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cochlea converts sound to electrical signals. The ossicles amplify vibrations. The semicircular canals help with balance. The pinna specifically collects and funnels sound waves.

questions.question_text: A submarine sends an ultrasonic signal which returns after 1.5 seconds. The speed of sound in seawater is 1530 m/s. How far away is the object?
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = v × t = 1530 × 1.5 = 2295 m. Since the signal travels to the object and back, distance = 2295/2 = 1147.5 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Round-trip distance = 1530 × 1.5 = 2295 m. Actual distance to object = 2295/2 = 1147.5 m. Always divide by 2 for echo-based calculations.
